docs.lead_paragraph: A couple sits across from me in my clinic. Holding hands and grinning widely, the woman tells me that she tested positive on a home pregnancy test. This joyful conversation goes on in doctors' offices thousands of times a day. As a pediatrician, however, it is rarely news I am overjoyed to hear. Both of these parents-to-be are under age 17. Each year more than a million American teenagers become pregnant. Four out of 10 opt for abortion. Fewer than a third of teenage mothers finish high school. Their babies have a higher risk of low-birth weight and its many complications. These dismal facts were hardly abstractions to me; children having children have always been a part of my practice and I have necessarily worked through this one patient at a time.

headline.main: Data Can't Diagnose the Human Condition

docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel column on treating teenager who chose to become pregnant despite being HIV positive; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The news that Laura Schlessinger has made a deal with Paramount for a syndicated television show beginning this fall has stirred up a fresh commotion about the most popular voice on talk radio. To her critics, Ms. Schlessinger is the Queen of Hate Radio, a bully with a particular animus toward homosexuality.

docs.lead_paragraph: This 60-second television commercial is Vice President Al Gore's first of the general-election season. It was made quickly last week in response to the first commercial broadcast by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, in which Mr. Bush says education has stagnated under the Clinton-Gore administration. PRODUCER: Century Media

docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption on Sunday about Asian-Americans who are eager to bear children in the Year of the Golden Dragon misidentified the health educator shown leading a neonatal class at the Chinatown Health Clinic. She was Ying Kuang, not Brenda Wan, also a health educator at the clinic.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Oscar Dressing Game This week the fashion world is engaged in the purest form of gossip it engages in all year. No one is talking about who is moving to what design house or who is acquiring what label or who is marrying, bedding or backstabbing whom. No, this week the fashion world is focusing quite simply on who is wearing what. Who is wearing what, of course, to the most-watched clothing show of all, the Academy Awards, which will be broadcast on Sunday night.

headline.main: Front Row; For designers, it's Oscar anticipation time again: will anyone wear their dress? After 25 years, Nova magazine will return.

docs.abstract: Front Page column discusses who will wear what at Academy Awards (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With more than three months to go in its term, the Supreme Court on Monday will enter a concentrated period of unusual intensity and potential import. The justices, back from a brief recess, will begin six weeks of hearing arguments in one blockbuster case after another, a series of high-profile appeals that appear drawn from today's headlines and that have already marked the term as a likely landmark. These questions suggest the scope of what awaits the justices among the two dozen cases they will hear between now and the last week in April, the final building blocks of the 1999-2000 term:

headline.main: Weighty Cases Crowd Last 3 Months of the Term

docs.abstract: Focus on major cases facing US Supreme Court in final three months of current term; court will hear Texas school district's appeal of ruling that bars practice of student-led prayers at public high school football games; will hear challenge to federal prosecution for burning down a private residence, focusing on whether Congress intended federal arson law to apply to private home and whether Congress had authority to do so under power to regulate interstate commerce; will examine constitutionality of Massachusetts' Burma law, which prohibits state agencies from doing business with companies that do business in Myanmar; will rule on decision by Virginia appeals court effectively overturning Miradna ruling governing admissibility of confessions in federal prosecutions; will examine Nebraska law criminalizing partial-birth abortion; will rule on whether Boy Scouts have right, under First Amendment, to exclude gay members (M)
docs.snippet: With more than three months to go in its term, the Supreme Court on Monday will enter a concentrated period of unusual intensity and potential import. The justices, back from a brief recess, will begin six weeks of hearing arguments in one...

docs.lead_paragraph: Millennium, schmillennium. It's the Year of the Dragon, baby. And among Asian-Americans who abide by the lunar calendar, this auspicious season of the mythical beast is also turning out to be the year of the baby boom.

headline.main: Year of the Dragon And the Diaper Pail; Favored Sign of Lunar Calendar Inspires an Asian Baby Boomlet

docs.abstract: Many Asian-Americans have apparently timed pregnancies to lunar calendar's Year of Dragon, which began Feb 5 and is deemed auspicious birth year; increased numbers of pregnancies in New York City's Asian neighborhoods noted; photo; drawings; chart of lunar years (M)
docs.snippet: Millennium, schmillennium.     It's the Year of the Dragon, baby. And among Asian-Americans who abide by the lunar calendar, this auspicious season of the mythical beast is also turning out to be the year of the baby boom.

docs.lead_paragraph: WILSON-Malcolm, former Governor, State of New York, on March 13, 2000. Devoted husband of the late Katharine McCloskey Wilson. Devoted father of Kathy Wilson Conroy and Anne Wilson Matthews. Brother of the late Irene Wilson Baker, Donald C. Wilson and Mary Jane Wilson Couzens. Grandfather of Sean, Chris, Emmet, Brendan and Greg Conroy and David Matthews. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath &Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Tuesday and Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial Church of The Holy Family, New Rochelle, NY on Thursday March 16 at 10:30 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Malcolm Wilson Scholarship Fund, Fordham Prepatory School, East Fordham Rd, Bronx, New York 10458 or The Katharine McCloskey Wilson Scholarship Fund, Notre Dame School of Manhattan, 104 St. Mark's Place, New York, NY 10009 WILSON-Malcolm, Governor. In his ode to statesmanship, 17th Century Thomas Dekker must have had Governor Wilson in mind: ''The best of men that ever wore earth about him was a sufferer, a soft, meek, patient, humble, tranquil spirit. The first gentleman that ever breathed!''. He lent legitimacy to government and elegance to the governed. In an era when the young were trampled underfoot in society's indifference, Malcolm Wilson stood so very tall in his dynamic concern for the troubled families and legions of the young who landed on the doorstep of Daytop Village. A huge part of his life is written in the grateful prayers of the rescued. His were the words of 12th Century St. Bernard: ''Prayer is a wine which makes glad the heart of man!''. May he rest with God! (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien, President Daytop Village, Inc. WILSON-Hon. Malcolm. Fordham University and the Board of Trustees mourn the loss of our colleague and loyal friend, Malcolm Wilson. A graduate of Fordham Preparatory School, Fordham College and the Fordham School of Law, Governor Wilson was among the first laymen appointed to Fordham's Board of Trustee in 1969. His Board service continued until he took the oath of office of the Governor and again later as Trustee Emeritus until his recent death. His concern and commitment to Fordham University as a Trustee and in many other roles will always be remembered. Our thoughts and prayers are with his daughters and their families. Paul B. Gunther Chair of the Board Joseph A. O'Hare, S.J. President WILSON-Hon. Malcolm. The Board of Trustees of Saint Patrick's Cathedral records with sorrow the passing of Malcolm Wilson who has served as a Trustee of Saint Patrick's Cathedral for 21 years with great dedication, holding the offices of Vice President and Secretary of the Board, and also serving as Chairman of the standing committees and many ad hoc committees. His wisdom, leadership and wit will be sorely missed by the members of the Board. To his bereaved family we extend our heartfelt condolences. John Cardinal O'Connor, President Rev. Msgr. James K. Vaughey, Executive Director WILSON-Malcolm. The Board of Trustees and Directors of Pregnancy Care Center mourn the passing of a much admired, respected and esteemed friend. Governor Malcolm Wilson will be remembered for his tireless efforts and proven dedication to the rights of the ''Unborn''. An exemplary Christian man, whose compassion, humanity and warm sensitivity touched the lives of all New Yorkers. The Pregnancy Care Center WILSON-Malcolm. Fordham University School of Law records with great sorrow the passing of Governor Malcolm Wilson, one of its most distinguished graduates, Class of 1936, and a role model extraordinaire as a citizen of New York. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Our love and prayers are with them. John D. Feerick, Dean WILSON-Malcolm. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Malcolm Wilson, a Veteran Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, Pres. Henry F. White, Historian
